'''Inverse distance weighting''' ('''IDW''') is a type of [[Deterministic algorithm|deterministic method]] for [[multivariate interpolation]] with a known scattered set of points. The assigned values to unknown points are calculated with a [[Weighted mean|weighted average]] of the values available at the known points.
The name given to this type of methods was motivated by the [[Weighted mean|weighted average]] applied, since it resorts to the inverse of the distance to each known point ("amount of proximity") when assigning weights.
==Definition of the problem== The expected result is a discrete assignment of the unknown function <math>u</math> in a study region:
:<math>u(x): x \to \mathbb{R}, \quad x \in \mathbf{D} \sub \mathbb{R}^n,</math>
where <math>\mathbf{D}</math> is the study region.
The set of <math>N</math> known data points can be described as a list of [[tuple]]s:
:<math>[(x_1, u_1), (x_2, u_2), ..., (x_N, u_N)].</math>
The function is to be "smooth" (continuous and once differentiable), to be exact (<math>u(x_i) = u_i</math>) and to meet the user's intuitive expectations about the phenomenon under investigation. Furthermore, the function should be suitable for a computer application at a reasonable cost (nowadays, a basic implementation will probably make use of [[parallel computing|parallel resources]]).
== Shepard's method ==
=== Historical reference === At the Harvard Laboratory for Computer Graphics and Spatial Analysis, beginning in 1965, a varied collection of scientists converged to rethink, among other things, what we now call [[geographic information system]]s.<ref>{{cite news |last=Chrisman |first=Nicholas |title=History of the Harvard Laboratory for Computer Graphics: a Poster Exhibit | url=http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic39008.files/History_LCG.pdf }}</ref>
The motive force behind the Laboratory, Howard Fisher, conceived an improved computer mapping program that he called SYMAP, which, from the start, Fisher wanted to improve on the interpolation. He showed Harvard College freshmen his work on SYMAP, and many of them participated in Laboratory events. One freshman, Donald Shepard, decided to overhaul the interpolation in SYMAP, resulting in his famous article from 1968.<ref name=shepardArticle>{{cite conference |last=Shepard |first=Donald |year=1968 |title=A two-dimensional interpolation function for irregularly-spaced data |booktitle=Proceedings of the 1968 [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] National Conference |pages = 517–524 |doi=10.1145/800186.810616 }}</ref>
Shepard’s algorithm was also influenced by the theoretical approach of [[William Warntz]] and others at the Lab who worked with spatial analysis. He conducted a number of experiments with the exponent of distance, deciding on something closer to the gravity model (exponent of -2). Shepard implemented not just basic inverse distance weighting, but also he allowed barriers (permeable and absolute) to interpolation.
Other research centers were working on interpolation at this time, particularly University of Kansas and their SURFACE II program. Still, the features of SYMAP were state-of-the-art, even though programmed by an undergraduate.
=== Basic form === [[Image:Shepard interpolation 2.png|thumb|640px|center|Shepard's interpolation for different power parameters ''p'', from scattered points on the surface <math>z=\exp(-x^2-y^2)</math>]]
A general form of finding an interpolated value <math>u</math> at a given point <math>x</math> based on samples <math>u_i=u(x_i)</math> for <math>i=1,2,...,N</math> using IDW is an interpolating function:
:<math>u(\mathbf{x}) = \begin{cases} \dfrac{\sum_{i = 1}^{N}{ w_i(\mathbf{x}) u_i } }{ \sum_{i = 1}^{N}{ w_i(\mathbf{x}) } }, & \text{if } d(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}_i) \neq 0 \text{ for all } i, \\ u_i, & \text{if } d(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}_i) = 0 \text{ for some } i, \end{cases} </math>
where
:<math>w_i(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{1}{d(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}_i)^p}</math>
is a simple IDW weighting function, as defined by Shepard,<ref name=shepardArticle/> '''x''' denotes an interpolated (arbitrary) point, '''x'''<sub>''i''</sub> is an interpolating (known) point, <math>d</math> is a given distance ([[Metric (mathematics)|metric]] operator) from the known point '''x'''<sub>''i''</sub> to the unknown point '''x''', ''N'' is the total number of known points used in interpolation and <math>p</math> is a positive real number, called the power parameter.
Here weight decreases as distance increases from the interpolated points. Greater values of <math>p</math> assign greater influence to values closest to the interpolated point, with the result turning into a mosaic of tiles (a [[Voronoi diagram]]) with nearly constant interpolated value for large values of ''p''. For two dimensions, power parameters <math>p \leq 2</math> cause the interpolated values to be dominated by points far away, since with a density <math>\rho</math> of data points and neighboring points between distances <math>r_0</math> to <math>R</math>, the summed weight is approximately :<math>\sum_j w_j \approx \int_{r_0}^R \frac{2\pi r\rho \,dr}{r^p} = 2\pi\rho\int_{r_0}^R r^{1-p} \,dr,</math> which diverges for <math>R\rightarrow\infty</math> and <math>p\leq2</math>. For ''N'' dimensions, the same argument holds for <math>p\leq N</math>. For the choice of value for ''p'', one can consider the degree of smoothing desired in the interpolation, the density and distribution of samples being interpolated, and the maximum distance over which an individual sample is allowed to influence the surrounding ones.
''Shepard's method'' is a consequence of minimization of a functional related to a measure of deviations between [[tuple]]s of interpolating points {'''x''', ''u''} and ''i'' tuples of interpolated points {'''x'''<sub>''i''</sub>, ''u<sub>i</sub>''}, defined as: :<math>\phi(\mathbf{x}, u) = \left( \sum_{i = 0}^{N}{\frac{(u-u_i)^2}{d(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}_i)^p}} \right)^{\frac{1}{p}} ,</math> derived from the minimizing condition: :<math>\frac{\partial \phi(\mathbf{x}, u)}{\partial u} = 0.</math>
The method can easily be extended to other dimensional spaces and it is in fact a generalization of Lagrange approximation into a multidimensional spaces. A modified version of the algorithm designed for trivariate interpolation was developed by Robert J. Renka and is available in [[Netlib]] as algorithm 661 in the toms library.
=== Example in 1 dimension === [[Image:Shepard interpolation 1 dimension.png|thumb|640px|center|Shepard's interpolation in 1 dimension, from 4 scattered points and using ''p'' = 2]]
=== Łukaszyk–Karmowski metric === Yet another modification of the Shepard's method was proposed by Łukaszyk<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Computational Mechanics| volume= 33| issue=4| pages=299–304| doi=10.1007/s00466-003-0532-2| title=A new concept of probability metric and its applications in approximation of scattered data sets| author=Łukaszyk S.}}</ref> also in applications to experimental mechanics. The proposed weighting function had the form
:<math>w_k(\mathbf{x}) = \frac{1}{(D_{**}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}_k) )^\frac{1}{2}},</math>
where <math>D_{**}(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}_k)</math> is the [[Łukaszyk–Karmowski metric]] chosen also with regard to the [[statistical error]] [[probability distribution]]s of measurement of the interpolated points.
=== Modified Shepard's method ===
Another modification of Shepard's method calculates interpolated value using only nearest neighbors within ''R''-sphere (instead of full sample). Weights are slightly modified in this case:
:<math>w_k(\mathbf{x}) = \left( \frac{\max(0,R-d(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}_k))}{R d(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}_k)} \right)^2.</math>
When combined with fast spatial search structure (like [[kd-tree]]), it becomes efficient ''N'' log ''N'' interpolation method suitable for large-scale problems.
== References == <references/>
== See also == * [[Multivariate interpolation]] * [[Kernel density estimation]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Inverse Distance Weighting}} [[Category:Geostatistics]] [[Category:Multivariate interpolation]]

{{Orphan|date=September 2017}}
{{Infobox protected area | name = Jasen | iucn_category = | iucn_ref = <!-- images --> | photo = National reserve jasen.JPG | photo_caption = Natural reserve Jasen <!-- map --> | map = | map_image = Macedonia location map.svg | map_size = | map_caption = | relief = <!-- location --> | location = [[Republic of Macedonia]] | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|41|51|56|N|21|16|55|E|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = <!-- stats --> | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_km2 = 240 | area_ref = | elevation = {{convert|2500|m|ft|abbr=on}} | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = <!-- dates & info --> | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = 1958 (2010) | named_for = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = | operator = | owner = <!-- website, embedded --> | website = {{Official website|http://jasen.com.mk/Default.aspx}} | embedded = }} The '''Public Enterprise for Managing and Protection of the Multipurpose Area Jasen''' ({{lang-mk|Јавно претпријатие за управување и заштита на повеќенаменското подрачје „Јасен“}}) or just '''Reservе Jasen''' ({{lang-mk|Резерват „Јасен“}}) is a nature reserve in the [[Republic of Macedonia]]. It was turned into a protected nature reserve in 2010 (part of it was declared a reserve as far back as 1958) and is situated only 15 km from [[Skopje]]. The park compromises around {{convert|24000|ha}} of caves, mountains, underground rivers and lakes. The lowest point is the still uncharted canyon lake Matka. The highest point is Mount Karadzica with a height of almost {{convert|2500|m}}.
The park is home to the endangered Eurasian lynx and the rare Balkan chamois.
==History== The territory of today's Public Enterprise for Managing and Protection of the Multipurpose Area Jasen was already in the period from 1958−1960 declared to be a reserve. The declaration had as goal the protection of the fauna, floral, biological, geological, natural and hydrological rarities.
== External links == {{commons category|Jasen}} *[http://www.jasen.com.mk/Default.aspx Official website of the park] *[http://www.balkansgeotourism.travel/content/yassen-jasen-reserve-macedonia/seeB6FEDF9CF446990A5 Yassen (Jasen) Reserve, Macedonia - Western Balkans Geotourism Mapguide], ''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]''

The '''list of ships of Algeria''' includes all [[ship]]s designed, built, or operated in or by [[Algeria]].
== Ship classes ==
=== [[Djebel Chenoua class patrol boat|''Djebel Chenoua'' class large patrol boat]] ===
* In service: 3 ships: [[Algerian patrol boat Djebel Chenoua|''Djebel Chenoua'' (351)]]; [[Algerian patrol boat El Chihab|''El Chihab'' (352)]]; [[Algerian patrol boat El Kirch|''El Kirch'' (353)]] * Displacement: 550 tons * Armament: 2 dual 14.5 mm machineguns * Larbi Ben M'Hidi Hyproc Shipping Company * Didouche Mourad - - -
=== [[Algerian auxiliary El Idrissi|''El Idrissi'' coastal survey ship]] ===
* Displacement: 540 tons * Crew: 28
=== [[Algerian auxiliary El Mourafik|''El Mourafik'' salvage ship]] ===
* Displacement: 1000 tons * Crew: 60 * Armament: 2 12.7 mm machineguns
=== [[Kalaat Beni Hammed class landing ship|''Kalaat Beni Hammed'' class small landing ship]] ===
* In service: 2 ships * Displacement: 2130 tons * Crew: 81 * Aircraft: Helicopter deck only * Capacity: 240 troops; 650 tons of cargo * Armament: Dual 40 mm AA gun; 2 25 mm AA guns
=== [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' (P4) class patrol boat]] ===
* In service: 8-10 ships plus 2-3 building * Displacement: 250 tons * Crew: 27 * Armament: Dual 25 mm AA guns; 2 14.5 mm machineguns * Note: Initial two ships carried a 76 mm OTO DP gun in place of the 25 mm guns.
=== [[Kilo class submarine|Rajs Hadi Mubarek (Project 887EKM Kilo) class diesel-electric submarine]] ===
* In service: 2 ships: 012 {{ship|Algerian submarine|Rajs Hadj Mubarek||2}}, 013 {{ship|Algerian submarine|El Hadj Slimane||2}} * Displacement: 3076 tons * Crew: 53 * Equipment: LF and HF sonar * Armament: 6 {{convert|21|in|mm|0|sing=on}} torpedo tubes with 18 torpedoes, [[3M-54 Kalibr|Club-S]] missiles.
=== [[Improved Kilo class submarine|Rais Hadi Slimane (Project 636M Improved Kilo) class diesel-electric submarine]] ===
* In service: 4 ships: 021 {{ship|Algerian submarine|Messali el Hadj||2}}, 022 {{ship|Algerian submarine|Akram Pacha||2}} and two with unknown name (shipyard numerals 01346 and 01347). * Displacement: 3126 tons * Crew: 53 * Equipment: LF and HF sonar * Armament: 6 {{convert|21|in|mm|0|sing=on}} torpedo tubes with 18 torpedoes, [[3M-54 Kalibr|Club-S]] missiles.
=== [[Koni class frigate|''Koni'' class light frigate]] ===
* In service: 3 ships: [[Algerian frigate Mourad Rais|''Mourad Rais'' (901)]]; [[Algerian frigate Rais Kellik|''Rais Kellik'' (902)]]; [[Algerian frigate Rais Korfu|''Rais Korfu'' (903)]] * Displacement: 1596 tons * Crew: 130 * Equipment: [[Strut Curve]] air and surface search radar, MF hull sonar, [[Pop Group]] missile control, [[Hawk Screech]] gun control, [[Drum Tilt]] gun control, [[Watch Dog]]{{dn|date=September 2018}} intercept * Armament: [[SA-8 Gecko|SA-N-4 Gecko SAM]] system with 20 missiles, 2 dual 76.2 mm DP guns, 2 dual 30 mm AA guns, 2 [[RBU-6000]] anti-submarine rocket systems, 2 depth-charge racks, mines * Note: Recent overhaul by Russia has added new search radar, an additional Drum Tilt, and 2 dual {{convert|21|in|mm|0|sing=on}} torpedo tubes to at least one ship, probably planned for installation on all ships.
=== [[Nanuchka class corvette|''Nanuchka II'' class corvette]] ===
* In service: 3 ships: [[Algerian corvette Rais Hamidou|''Rais Hamidou'' (801)]]; [[Algerian corvette Salah Rais|''Salah Rais'' (802)]]; [[Algerian corvette Rais Ali|''Rais Ali'' (803)]] * Displacement: 675 tons * Crew: 60 * Equipment: [[Square Tie]] surface search radar, [[Pop Group]] missile fire control, [[Muff Cob]] gun fire control, [[Bell Tap]] intercept, [[Cross Loop]] direction finder, chaff * Armament: 4 [[SS-N-2|SS-N-2C Styx SSM]]; [[SA-8 Gecko|SA-N-4 Gecko]] SAM system with 20 missiles; dual 57 mm DP gun * Note: Recent upgrade has added new search radar, replaced the Styx missiles with 16 [[Kh-35|SS-N-25 Kh-35]] SSM and the 57 mm guns with a single 30 mm AA gun.
=== [[Osa class missile boat|''Osa I'' class missile boat]] ===
* In service: 2 ships * Displacement: 209 tons * Crew: 30 * Equipment: [[Square Tie]] surface search radar, [[Drum Tilt]] gun fire control * Armament: 4 [[SS-N-2|SS-N-2A Styx SSM]]; 2 dual 30 mm AA guns
=== [[Osa class missile boat|''Osa II'' class missile boat]] ===
* In service: 9 ships * Displacement: 240 tons * Crew: 30 * Equipment: [[Square Tie]] surface search radar, [[Drum Tilt]] gun fire control * Armament: 4 [[SS-N-2|SS-N-2B Styx SSM]]; 2 dual 30 mm AA guns
=== [[Polnocny class landing ship|''Polnocny B'' class utility landing craft]] ===
* In service: 1 ship * Displacement: 800 tons * Crew: 40 * Capacity: 130 troops; 180 tons cargo * Armament: Dual 30 mm AA guns
== Individual ships ==
=== D ===
* [[Algerian patrol boat Djebel Chenoua|''Djebel Chenoua'']] (351): [[Djebel Chenoua class patrol boat|''Djebel Chenoua'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1988.
=== E ===
* [[Algerian patrol boat El Chihab|''El Chihab'']] (352): [[Djebel Chenoua class patrol boat|''Djebel Chenoua'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1995. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Djari|''El Djari'']] (346): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1986. * [[Algerian submarine El Hadi Slimane|''El Hadi Slimane'']] (O13): [[Kilo class submarine|''Kilo'' class]] submarine in active service, commissioned 1988. * [[Algerian auxiliary El Idrissi|''El Idrissi'']] (BH204): Japanese built coastal survey ship in active service, commissioned 1980. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Kechef|''El Kechef'']] (343): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1984. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Morakeb|''El Morakeb'']] (342): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1983. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Moukadem|''El Moukadem'']] (348): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service. * [[Algerian auxiliary El Mourafik|''El Mourafik'']] (261): Chinese built small salvage ship in active service, commissioned 1990. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Moutarid|''El Moutarid'']] (344): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1985. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Rassed|''El Rassed'']] (345): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1985. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Saher|''El Saher'']] (347): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Wafi|''El Wafi'']] (355): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service. * [[Algerian patrol boat El Yadekh|''El Yadekh'']] (341): [[Kebir class patrol boat|''Kebir'' class]] patrol boat in active service, commissioned 1982.
=== K ===
* [[Algerian landing ship Kalaat Beni Hammed|''Kalaat Beni Hammed'']] (472): United Kingdom ([[Brooke Marine]]) built landing ship (BDSL) in active service, commissioned 1984. * [[Algerian landing ship Kalaat Beni Rached|''Kalaat Beni Rached'']] (473): United Kingdom (Brooke Marine / Vosper Thornycroft) built landing ship (BDSL) in active service, commissioned 1984.

=== R ===

''For more information on main flags see article: [[Flag of Croatia]]''{{Refimprove|list|date=April 2010}} This is a list of flags which have been, or are still today, used in '''[[Croatia]]''' or by '''[[Croats]]'''. {{Commons category|Flags of Croatia}} == Current flags == === National flag === {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:110px;"|Flag !! style="width:250px;"|Date !! style="width:250px;"|Use !! style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia.svg|100px|border]] || 21 December 1990–present ||[[Flag of Croatia]] || Three equal horizontal fields, red on the top, white in the middle and blue on the bottom; the [[Coat of Arms of Croatia|national coat of arms]] in the centre. |} === Presidential standard === {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:110px;"|Flag !! style="width:250px;"|Date !! style="width:250px;"|Use !! style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of the President of Croatia.svg|100px]] || 1 November 1990–present || Standard of the [[President of Croatia]] || A square blue field with a border of red and white squares; in the center a version of the national coat of arms and a red-white-blue ribbon with the letters "RH" (the initials of the country's full name in Croatian, ''Republika Hrvatska''). |} === Maritime flags === {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:110px;"|Flag !! style="width:250px;"|Date !! style="width:250px;"|Use !! style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Civil Ensign of Croatia.svg|100px|border]] || || [[Civil ensign|Civil]] and [[state ensign]] of Croatia || Identical to the national flag, but with 2:3 proportions. |- | [[File:Naval Ensign of Croatia.svg|100px|border]] || 1 March 1999–present ||[[Naval ensign]] of Croatia (ensign of the [[Croatian Navy]]) || Same as the civil ensign, but with two crossed anchors behind the coat of arms. |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Croatia.svg|100px|border]] || 1 March 1999–present ||[[Naval jack]] of Croatia || A blue field with red and white border, with the national coat of arms and two crossed anchors in the centre. |} == Historical flags (tricolour) {{anchor|Historical flags}} == {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:110px;"|Flag !! style="width:250px;"|Date !! style="width:250px;"|Use !! style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia (1990).svg|100px|border]] || 27 June 1990–21 December 1990 || Early flag of the [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|Republic of Croatia]] (federal unit of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]). Also flag of Croatian political opposition in exile 1945 - 1990 {{cite video | people= | date=1990-06-20 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V8ath2k53vo | title=SRH preimenovana u RH |trans-title= Socialist Republic of Croatia is renamed to Republic of Croatia | medium=Motion picture, [[TV kalendar]] | location=[[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] | publisher=[[Croatian Radiotelevision]]}}|| Three equal horizontal fields, red on the top, white in the middle and blue on the bottom, Coat of arms of Croatia in the center of the middle field. The first field of the coat of arms was never specified in the Croatian constitution.
The flag used [[Republic of Croatia]] colors, proportions 1:2. |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia (1945–1990).svg|100px|border]] || 2 June 1945–27 June 1990 || Flag of [[Socialist Republic of Croatia]] (subdivision of [[SFR Yugoslavia]]). || A tricolour of red, white, and blue with a (golden-rimmed) red star in the center.
The flag used Yugoslav colors, proportions 1:2. |- | [[File:Croatian Partisans flag.svg|100px|border]] || 15 December 1943–2 June 1945 || Flag of the [[Federal State of Croatia]] (subdivision of [[Democratic Federal Yugoslavia|DF Yugoslavia]]) and also the Croatian branch of the Yugoslav Partisans, used during World War II.|| A tricolour of red, white, and blue with a red star in the center of middle field.
The flag used Yugoslav colors, proportions 1:2. |- | [[File:Early flag of the Yugoslav Partisans.svg|100px|border]] || 9 October 1941 –25 March 1942 || "Flag of Croatian-Serbian friendship", an early flag of the Yugoslav [[Yugoslav Partisans|Partisan movement]] || Early flag of the Yugoslav [[Yugoslav Partisans|Partisan movement]], divided (left half Croat, right half Serb flag).
The flag used Yugoslav colors, proportions 2:3. |- | [[File:Civil Flag of Banovina of Croatia.svg|100px|border]] || 21 November 1939–17 October 1943 (21 January 1941) || Flag of the [[Banovina of Croatia]] (subdivision of the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]). Used ''de facto'' 1939-1941; legally valid 1939-1943. || A tricolour of red, white, and blue.
The flag used Yugoslav colors, proportions 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of the State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs.svg|100px|border]] || 1918 || Flag of [[State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs]] || A tricolour of red, white, and blue.
The flag used Yugoslav colors, proportions 1:2. |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia-Slavonia.svg|100px|border]] || 1860–1918 || Flag of the [[Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]] (subdivision of the [[Austria-Hungary]]). Official on all levels. || A tricolour of red, white, and blue.
The flag used Croatian colors, proportions 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia-Slavonia with CoA.svg|100px|border]] || 1860–1918 || Flag of the [[Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia]] (subdivision of the [[Austria-Hungary]])., Internal flag, unofficial outside Croatia-Slavonia. || A tricolour of red, white, and blue, with the composite coat of arms of the Triune Kingdom superimposed and centred
The flag used Croatian colors, proportions 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of the Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg).svg|100px|border]] || 8 March 1852 – 1860 || Flag of the [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Kingdom of Croatia]] (subdivision of the [[Austrian Empire]]). Official on all levels. || Two bars of red and white.
The flag used Croatian colors, proportions 1:2. |- | [[File:Croatia-1848.gif|100px|border]] || 1848–1852 || Flag of the [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Kingdom of Croatia]] (subdivision of the [[Austrian Empire]]). Not used on the level of the [[Austrian Empire]]. || A tricolour of red, white, and blue with the triune coat of arms in the center.
The flag used Croatian colors, proportions 1:2. |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia-Slavonia.svg|100px|border]] || early 19th century–1848 || Unofficial flag of the [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Kingdom of Croatia]] (which at the time incorporated the subordinate [[Kingdom of Slavonia]]) within the [[Austrian Empire]] || A tricolour of red, white, and blue |} === Independent State of Croatia (1941–1945) === {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:110px;"|Flag !! style="width:250px;"|Date !! style="width:250px;"|Use !! style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Croatia Ustasa.svg|100px|border]] || 1941–1945 || Flag of the [[Independent State of Croatia]] (NDH) || A tricolour of red, white, and blue with the [[Ustaše]] symbol in top-left corner (letter "U" surrounded by [[Croatian interlace]]) and the Croatian coat of arms (but with the first field white, as opposed to red) in the center.

page.title: List of European regions by life expectancy

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=November 2018}}{{primary sources|date=November 2018}}}} This is a '''list of [[European region|European regions]] ([[Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics|NUTS2]] regions) sorted by their average [[Life expectancy]] at birth.''' [[Eurostat]] calculates the life expectancy based on the information provided by national statistics institutes affiliated to eurostat.The list presents statistics for 2016 from EUROSTAT, as of 3 June 2018. == 2016 list == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+'''List of EU regions and territories by life expectancy 2016''' !Region (NUTS2) !Country !Life expectancy at birth,

This is a '''list of ZIP code prefixes'''. Each cell in this table contains a three-digit ZIP code prefix, the state where that ZIP code prefix is located, and the name of the [[United States Postal Service]] (USPS) [[Sectional Center Facility]] (SCF) that serves that ZIP code prefix, which may be in a different state. Each SCF may serve more than one three-digit ZIP code prefix. Each SCF serves local addresses whose five-digit ZIP codes start with the same set of prefixes.
* An [[asterisk]] (*) indicates that the listed place name is the "default" place name for all addresses in the prefix.{{clarify|date=June 2016}} * A [[Dagger (typography)|dagger]] (†) indicates that the SCF serving this prefix is in a different state.

page.title: List of extreme summits of the Caribbean
List of international presidential trips made by Ronald Reagan

revision.comment: Removing from [[Category:United States history-related lists]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2018}} [[File:Ronald Reagan Overseas Visits.svg|thumb|right|260px|World map highlighting countries visited by Ronald Reagan while president.]] {{Ronald Reagan series}} This is a '''list of international presidential trips made by Ronald Reagan''', the [[List of Presidents of the United States|40th]] [[President of the United States|president]] of the [[United States]]. [[Ronald Reagan]] made 25 international trips to 26 different countries on four [[continents]]—Europe, Asia, North America, and South America—during his [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|presidency]], which began on [[First inauguration of Ronald Reagan|January 20, 1981]] and ended on [[Inauguration of George H. W. Bush|January 20, 1989]].{{cite web|url= https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/travels/president/reagan-ronald|title= Travels of President Ronald Reagan|publisher= U.S. Department of State Office of the Historian}} The number of visits per country where he travelled are: * One visit to [[Barbados]], [[Brazil]], [[China]], [[Colombia]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Finland]], [[Grenada]], [[Honduras]], [[Iceland]], [[Indonesia]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Jamaica]], [[Portugal]], [[South Korea]], [[Soviet Union]], [[Spain]], [[Switzerland]] * Two visits to [[Belgium]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], [[Vatican City]] * Three visits to [[United Kingdom]] * Four visits to [[France]] * Five visits to [[Canada]] * Six visits to [[Mexico]], [[West Germany]] ==1981== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |1 |January 5, 1981 |{{flag|Mexico}} |[[Cuidad Juarez]] |Met with President [[José López Portillo]]. (Visit made as President-elect.) |- |2 |March 10–11, 1981 |{{flag|Canada}} |[[Ottawa]] |State visit. Met with Governor General [[Edward Schreyer]] and Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]]. Addressed parliament. |- |3 |July 19–21, 1981 |{{flag|Canada}} |Ottawa,
[[Montebello, Quebec|Montebello]] |Attended the [[7th G7 summit]]. |- |4 |October 21–24, 1981 |{{flag|Mexico}} |[[Cancun]] |Attended the [[North–South Summit]] on International Cooperation and Development. Met with the heads of state and government of Algeria, Bangladesh, Canada, China, France, Guyana, India, Japan, Mexico, Nigeria, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, Tanzania, the United Kingdom, Venezuela and Yugoslavia. |} ==1982== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |- |rowspan=2|5 |April 7–8, 1982 |{{flag|Jamaica}} |[[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]] |Official visit. Met with Prime Minister [[Edward Seaga]]. |- |April 8–11, 1982 |{{flag|Barbados}} |[[Bridgetown]] |Official visit. Met with the prime ministers of Barbados, Dominica, Antigua and Barbuda, St. Christopher and Nevis, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. |- |rowspan=7|6 |June 2–7, 1982 |{{flag|France}} |[[Paris]] |State visit. Met with President [[François Mitterrand]] and Prime Minister [[Pierre Mauroy]]. |- |June 5–6, 1982 |{{flag|France}} |[[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] |Attended the [[8th G7 summit]]. |- |June 7, 1982 |{{flag|Italy}} |[[Rome]] |Met with President [[Sandro Pertini]] and Premier [[Giovanni Spadolini]]. |- |June 7, 1982 |{{flag|Vatican City}} |[[Apostolic Palace]] |Audience with Pope John Paul II. |- |June 7–9, 1982 |{{flag|United Kingdom}} |[[London]],
[[Windsor Castle]] |State visit. Met with Queen Elizabeth II and Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]]. Addressed Parliament. |- |June 9–11, 1982 |{{flag|West Germany}} |[[Bonn]] |State visit. Met with Chancellor [[Helmut Schmidt]] and President [[Karl Carstens]]. Addressed the [[Bundestag]] and attended a meeting of the North Atlantic Council. |- |June 11, 1982 |{{flag|West Germany}} |[[West Berlin]] |Met with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. |- |7 |October 8, 1982 |{{flag|Mexico}} |[[Tijuana]] |Exchange of visits with President-elect [[Miguel de la Madrid]]. |- |rowspan=4|8 |November 30 – December 3, 1982 |{{flag|Brazil|1968}} |[[Brasília]],
[[São Paulo]] |Official working visit. Met with President [[João Figueiredo]]. |- |December 3, 1982 |{{flag|Colombia}} |[[Bogotá|Bogota]] |Official working visit. Met with President [[Belisario Betancur]]. |- |December 3–4, 1982 |{{flag|Costa Rica}} |[[San José, Costa Rica|San José]] |Official working visit. Met with President [[Luis Alberto Monge]] and President [[Álvaro Magaña]] of El Salvador. |- |December 4, 1982 |{{flag|Honduras}} |[[San Pedro Sula]] |Official working visit. Met with President [[Roberto Suazo Córdova]] and with Guatemalan President [[Efraín Ríos Montt]]. |} ==1983== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |9 |August 14, 1983 |{{flag|Mexico}} |[[La Paz, Baja California Sur|La Paz]] |Informal meeting with President Miguel de la Madrid. |- |rowspan=2|10 |November 9–12, 1983 |{{flag|Japan|1947}} |[[Tokyo]] |State visit. Met with Emperor [[Hirohito]] and Prime Minister [[Yasuhiro Nakasone]] and addressed the [[Diet of Japan|Diet]]. |- |November 12–14, 1983 |{{flag|South Korea|1949}} |[[Seoul]],
[[Korean Demilitarized Zone|Demilitarized Zone]] |State visit. Met with President [[Chun Doo-hwan]]. Addressed the [[National Assembly of South Korea|National Assembly]] and visited U.S. troops. |} ==1984== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |11 |April 26 – May 1, 1984 |{{flag|China}} |[[Beijing]],
[[Xian]],
[[Shanghai]] |State visit. Met with President [[Li Xiannian]] and Premier [[Zhao Ziyang]]. |- |rowspan=3|12 |June 1–4, 1984 |{{flag|Ireland}} |[[Shannon, County Clare|Shannon]], [[Galway]], [[Ballyporeen]], [[Dublin]] |Met with President [[Patrick Hillery]] and Prime Minister [[Garret FitzGerald]]. Visited ancestral home. Addressed [[Oireachtas|Parliament]]. |- |June 4–10, 1984 |{{flag|United Kingdom}} |London |Attended the [[10th G7 summit]]. |- |June 6, 1984 |{{flag|France}} |[[Normandy]] |Attended commemorative ceremonies of the 40th anniversary of the [[Normandy landings|Allied landing in Normandy]]. Also present were Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands]], King [[Olav V of Norway]], King [[Baudouin I of Belgium]], French President François Mitterrand, Queen Elizabeth II and [[Jean, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]]. |} ==1985== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |13 |March 17–18, 1985 |{{flag|Canada}} |[[Quebec City]] |Met with Prime Minister [[Brian Mulroney]]. |- |rowspan=5|14 |April 30 – May 4, 1985 |{{flag|West Germany}} |Bonn |Attended the [[11th G7 summit]]. |- |May 5–6, 1985 |{{flag|West Germany}} |Bonn,
[[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]],
[[Bitburg]],
[[Hambach Castle]] |State visit. Attended ceremonies commemorating 40th anniversary of the [[Victory in Europe Day|end of World War II in Europe]]. |- |May 6–8, 1985 |{{flag|Spain}} |[[Madrid]] |State visit. Met with King [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] and [[Prime Minister of Spain#Official title|President]] [[Felipe González]]. |- |May 8, 1985 |{{flag|France}} |[[Strasbourg]] |Addressed the [[European Parliament]]. |- |May 8–10, 1985 |{{flag|Portugal}} |[[Lisbon]] |State visit. Met with President [[António Ramalho Eanes]] and Prime Minister [[Mário Soares]]. Addressed the [[Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)|National Assembly]]. |- |rowspan=2|15 |November 16–21, 1985 |{{flag|Switzerland}} |[[Geneva]] |Attended the [[Geneva Summit (1985)|Summit Meeting]] with [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Soviet General Secretary]] [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]. Met also with Swiss President [[Kurt Furgler]]. |- |November 21, 1985 |{{flag|Belgium}} |[[Brussels]] |Attended the [[1985 Brussels summit|NATO Summit Meeting]]. Present were the Heads of State and Government of Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Luxembourg, Portugal, Turkey and the United Kingdom. |} ==1986== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |16 |January 3, 1986 |{{flag|Mexico}} |[[Mexicali]] |Informal meeting with President Miguel de la Madrid. |- |17 |February 20, 1986 |{{flag|Grenada}} |[[St. George's, Grenada|St. George's]] |Met with Governor General [[Paul Scoon]] and Prime Minister [[Herbert Blaize]], and with the Prime Ministers of Barbados, Dominica, Jamaica, St. Lucia, St. Christopher and Nevis, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Antigua and Barbuda, and Trinidad and Tobago. Dedicated a memorial to U.S. servicemen. |- |rowspan=2|18 |April 29 – May 2, 1986 |{{flag|Indonesia}} |[[Bali]] |Attended the ASEAN Ministerial Meeting. Met with Indonesian President [[Suharto]] and Philippine Vice President [[Salvador Laurel]]. |- |May 2–7, 1986 |{{flag|Japan|1947}} |Tokyo |Attended the [[12th G7 summit]]. |- |19 |October 9–12, 1986 |{{flag|Iceland}} |[[Reykjavík]] |[[Reykjavík Summit|Pre-Summit Meeting]] with Soviet General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev. Met with President [[Vigdís Finnbogadóttir]]. |} ==1987== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |20 |April 4–5, 1987 |{{flag|Canada}} |Ottawa |State visit. Met with Governor General [[Jeanne Sauvé]] and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. Addressed parliament. |- |rowspan=4|21 |June 3–11, 1987 |{{flag|Italy}} |[[Venice]],
Rome |Attended the [[13th G7 summit]]. Met with President [[Francesco Cossiga]] and Prime Minister [[Amintore Fanfani]] in Rome. |- |June 6, 1987 |{{flag|Vatican City}} |Apostolic Palace |Audience with Pope John Paul II. |- |June 11–12, 1987 |{{flag|West Germany}} |West Berlin |Attended celebration's commemorating the 750th Anniversary of the founding of Berlin. Met with Chancellor [[Helmut Kohl]]. |- |June 12, 1987 |{{flag|West Germany}} |Bonn |Met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl. |} [[File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg|thumb|350px|center|Ronald Reagan speaks at the [[Berlin Wall]]'s [[Brandenburg Gate]], challenging [[Mikhail Gorbachev|Gorbachev]] to "[[tear down this wall!]]"]] ==1988== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 3%;"| !style="width: 17%;"|Dates !style="width: 13%;"|Country !style="width: 12%;"|Locations !style="width: 55%;"|Details |- |22 |February 13, 1988 |{{flag|Mexico}} |[[Mazatlan]] |Informal meeting with President Miguel de la Madrid. Signed textile agreement. |- |23 |March 1–3, 1988 |{{flag|Belgium}} |[[Brussels]] |Attended the [[1988 Brussels summit|NATO Summit Meeting]]. Present were the Heads of State and Government of Canada, Denmark, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Turkey and the United Kingdom. |- |rowspan=3|24 |May 25, 1988 |{{flag|Finland}} |[[Helsinki]] |Met with President [[Mauno Koivisto]] and Prime Minister [[Harri Holkeri]]. |- |May 29 – June 2, 1988 |{{flag|Soviet Union}} |[[Moscow]] |Summit meeting with General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev. Exchanged ratifications of the [[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty|INF Treaty]]. |- |June 2–3, 1988 |{{flag|United Kingdom}} |London |Met with Queen Elizabeth II, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Japanese Prime Minister [[Noboru Takeshita]]. |- |25 |June 19–21, 1988 |{{flag|Canada}} |[[Toronto]] |Attended the [[14th G7 summit]]. |} ==Multilateral meetings==
{| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%; text-align:center;" |- !rowspan="2"|Group !!colspan="8"|Year |- !1981 !!1982 !!1983 !!1984 !!1985 !!1986 !!1987 !!1988 |- |'''[[G7]]''' || [[7th G7 summit|July 20–21]],
{{flagicon|Canada}} [[Montebello, Quebec|Montebello]]||[[8th G7 summit|June 4–6]],
{{flagicon|France}} [[Versailles]] ||[[9th G7 summit|May 28–30]],
{{flagicon|United States}} [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]] ||[[10th G7 summit|June 7–9]],
{{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[London]] ||[[11th G7 summit|May 2–4]],
{{flagicon|West Germany}} [[Bonn]] ||[[12th G7 summit|May 4–6]],
{{flagicon|Japan}} [[Tokyo]] ||[[13th G7 summit|June 8–10]],
{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Venice]] ||[[14th G7 summit|July 20–21]],
{{flagicon|Canada}} [[Toronto]] |- |'''[[NATO summit|NATO]]''' ||style="background:#dcdcdc;"|''none''||[[1982 Bonn summit|June 10]],
{{flagicon|West Germany}} [[Bonn]]||style="background:#dcdcdc;"|''none''||style="background:#dcdcdc;"|''none''||[[1985 Brussels summit|November 21]],
{{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Brussels]]||style="background:#dcdcdc;"|''none''||style="background:#dcdcdc;"|''none''||[[1988 Brussels summit|March 2–3]],
{{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Brussels]] |- |}

revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=June 2010}}
{{Expand German|Liste der Wiener Märkte|date=June 2010}} [[File:Wien - Naschmarkt.JPG|thumb|upright=1.4|Naschmarkt]] List of Markets in Vienna: <!-- In [[Wien]] gibt es zahlreiche [[Markt|Märkte]], die die Versorgung der Bevölkerung in großem Maß prägen.
Die '''26 Wiener Märkte''' beherbergen auf ihren 90.000 Quadratmetern Gesamtmarktfläche 900 ständige Marktbetriebe, 600 tageweise Marktbezieher (Bauern and Händler) sowie 4.000 Arbeitnehmer. Die Wiener Märkte erwirtschaften einen Umsatz von 300 Millionen Euro and damit 4 Prozent des Gesamtumsatzes des Wiener Handels. 21 Märkte finden täglich von Monday til Saturday statt. -->
== 1st District ([[Innere Stadt]]) == '''[[Markt am Donaukanal]]''' * Place: [[Zwischen Augartenbrücke and Aspernbrücke * Opening hours: Mai til September Saturday 14-20 o'clock, Sunday 10-20 o'clock * Accessibility: [[Vienna U-Bahn|U4]] * Kunstgewerbe, Kunstgegenstände, Antiquitäten, books
'''Antiquitätenmarkt [[Am Hof]]'''<ref>[[:de:Am Hof]]</ref> * Place: Rund um die [[Mariensäule]] {{coord|48|12|39.95|N|16|22|2.81|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Antiquitätenmarkt Am Hof}} * Opening hours 1.03. til Saturday vor 24.12: Friday and Saturday 10-20 o'clock Angebot: Kunstgegenstände and Antiquitäten * Accessibility: 1A, 2A, 3A
'''Biobauern-Markt [[Freyung (Vienna)|Freyung]]''' * Place: Freyung {{coord|48|12|42.24|N|16|21|54.46|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Biobauern-Markt Freyung}} * Opening hours: Ganzjährig in allen ungeraden Kalenderwochen, Friday and Saturday 9-18 o'clock * Accessibility: 1A Freyung. [[Vienna U-Bahn|U2]] [[Schottentor]], [[Vienna U-Bahn|U3]] [[Herrengasse]] * Lebensmittel aus kontrolliert biologischem Anbau
'''Temporärer Markt Freyung''' * Place: Freyung {{coord|48|12|42.24|N|16|21|54.46|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Temporärer Markt Freyung}} * Opening hours: May til November, Tuesday til Thursday 10-18.30 o'clock Angebot: Lebensmittel (mit Landparteien) * Accessibility: 1A Freyung, [[Vienna U-Bahn|U2]] [[Schottentor]], [[Vienna U-Bahn|U3]] [[Herrengasse]]
; Former markets: * [[Bauernmarkt]] * [[Fleischmarkt]], [[Greek Quarter]]<ref>[[:de:Griechenviertel (Wien)]]</ref> * [[Getreidemarkt]] * Am Haarmarkt (also Flachsmarkt, now [[Rotenturmstraße]]) * [[Hoher Markt]]<ref>[[:de:Hoher Markt]]</ref> * Am Kienmarkt (now [[Ruprechtsplatz]]) * [[Kohlmarkt]] (formerly Witmarkt, Kohlenmarkt)<ref>[[:de:Kohlmarkt (Wien)]]</ref> * [[Neuer Markt]] (formerly Mehlmarkt)<ref>[[Neuer Markt (Wien)]]</ref> * Am Rossmarkt (now [[Renngasse]]) * [[Salzgasse]] * Schweinemarkt (now [[Lobkowitzplatz]]) * [[Wildpretmarkt]] (formerly Neuer Kienmarkt)
== 2nd District ([[Leopoldstadt]]) == [[File:Karmelitermarkt.jpg|thumb|Karmelitermarkt]] '''[[Karmelitermarkt]]'''<ref>[[:de:Karmelitermarkt]]</ref> * Place: [[Im Werd]], [[Krummbaumgasse]], [[Leopoldsgasse]], [[Haidgasse]] {{coord|48|13|2.56|N|16|22|35.56|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Karmelitermarkt}} * Opening hours: Monday til Friday 6-19.30 o'clock, Saturday 6-17 o'clock * [[Gastronomy]]: Monday til Saturday/Shabbath 6 til 22 o'clock * Accessibility: [[Wiener Linien|5A]], nearby [[Karmeliterplatz]], and part of the [[Karmeliterviertel]]<ref>[[:de:Karmeliterviertel|(de)]]</ref> * Bio-Eck jeden Saturday/Shabbath, market with farmhouse market
'''[[Vorgartenmarkt]]''' * Place: [[Wohlmutstraße]], [[Ennsgasse]] {{coord|48|13|17.99|N|16|24|5.64|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Vorgartenmarkt}} * Opening hours: Monday til Friday 6-19.30 o'clock, Saturday 6-17 o'clock * [[Gastronomy]]: Monday til Saturday 6 til 22 o'clock * Accessibility: 82A * market with farmhouse market

'''[[Temporärer Markt Mariahilfer Straße]]''' * Place: Vorplatz]] der [[Kirche Maria Hilf]] {{coord|48|11|57.05|N|16|21|8.91|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Temporärer Markt Mariahilfer Straße}} * Opening hours: Monday, Wednesday, Friday 9-18:30 o'clock, Saturday 9-14 o'clock, erster Saturday/Monat 9-18 o'clock * Accessibility: [[Vienna U-Bahn|U3]], 2A, 13A, 14A
== 10th District == '''[[Viktor-Adler-markt]]''' * Place: [[Viktor-Adler-Platz]] {{coord|48|10|36.24|N|16|22|33.45|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Viktor-Adler-Markt}} * Opening hours: Monday til Friday 6-19.30 o'clock, Saturday 6-17 o'clock * Gastronomie Monday til Saturday 6 til 22 o'clock * Accessibility: [[Vienna U-Bahn|U1]], 6, 14A, 67 * market with farmhouse market
== 11th District == [[File:Simmeringer Markt Marktamt.jpg|thumb|Simmeringer Markt, denkmalgeschütztes Marktamts-Gebäude]] '''[[Simmeringer Markt]]''' * Place: [[Geiselbergstraße]], [[Lorystraße]] {{coord|48|10|26.94|N|16|24|42.45|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Simmeringer Markt}} * Opening hours: Seit 2009 geschlossen<ref>[http://www.wien.gv.at/bezirke/simmering/bildung/bildungszentrum.html wien.at – Spatenstich für neues Bildungszentrum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329010930/http://www.wien.gv.at/bezirke/simmering/bildung/bildungszentrum.html |date=2010-03-29 }}</ref> * Accessibility: [[Vienna U-Bahn|U3]] ([[Enkplatz]]), 6 * Ursprünglicher Standort war im 19. Jahrhundert der Enkplatz, im Zuge des Baus der [[Neusimmeringer Pfarrkirche]] wurde der Markt zuerst in die Sedlitzkygasse and dann hierher verlegt. Bis Mai 2009 befand sich hier ein Markt with farmhouse market and Gastronomie, seither wird das Areal in ein Bildungszentrum umgebaut. In das denkmalgeschützten Marktamtsgebäude soll eine Kinderbücherei einziehen, die ebenfalls unter Denkmalschutz stehende öffentliche WC-Anlage wird als Zugang zu einer Volksgarage genutzt.
== 12th District == '''[[Meidlinger Markt]]''' * Place: [[Niederhofstraße]], [[Rosaliagasse]], [[Reschgasse]], [[Ignazgasse]] {{coord|48|10|50.62|N|16|19|57.72|E|type:landmark_dim:100_region:AT-9|name=Meidlinger Markt}} * Opening hours: Monday til Friday 6-19.30 o'clock, Saturday 6-17 o'clock * [[Gastronomy]]: Monday til Saturday 6 til 21 o'clock * Accessibility: [[Vienna U-Bahn|U6]], 10A, 63A * market with farmhouse market
